subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to write the assertion?
msgSnippet: ... Did you actually experience this? As far as I know, Scrum doesn t say much about testing (or coding) at all - which is way many teams adopt XP practices
messageBody:
> As an example, using the Agile method (scrums, sprints) where
> a sprint of 28 days is in place code is not ready for testing
> until maybe the 21 day.

Did you actually experience this?

As far as I know, Scrum doesn't say much about testing (or coding) at all -
which is way many teams adopt XP practices for this part of the process.

XP, on the other hand, *requires* that the customer representative expresses
the requirements in executable (QA style) acceptance tests, which need to be
ready at the end of the iteration (sprint). It also encourages developers to
produce fully working, integrated and unit tested code from day one.

So I'm not sure where your impression is coming from; to me it doesn't sound
like a team where that can happen really has groked Agile software
development.


> In my experience the project managers
> for sprints do not understand the need for engineering specs,
> hence they do not exist, or if they do they are after the
> fact.

I'm not sure what you mean by "engineering specs", but I also don't
understand why the project manager has to understand their need for them to
be produced at the right time. It's the responsibility of the team to
produce what is needed when it's needed.

> There is no time in the plan for rework of bad code.

If you need time in the plan for rework, you are not doing enough of it.
Refactoring, as we call reworking code in small very controlled steps,
should be part of the developers minute-to-minute work. They should be doing
so much of it, so tightly intermingled with the rest of their work, that
it's impossible to measure how much of their time they are spending doing
it.

> There is no time in the sprint for rigorous QA.

QA should be an ongoing effort during the sprint, parallel to the rest of
the work. If there is "no time" for this, the team really is not a truly
Agile one.

> This leads to quantity not quality.

Agreed. But it has nothing to do with Agility.

> Remember that satellite that crashed in the
> planet Mars because different methods of measuring speed were
> used. Effective integration testing would have caught that problem.

As would have better communication and collaboration. That hardly was an
Agile project, was it? ;)

Cheers, Ilja
